...I will apply dietetic measures for the benefit of the sick according to my ability and judgment; I will keep them from harm and injustice.
 
 I will neither give a deadly drug to anybody who asked for it, nor will I make a suggestion to this effect. Similarly I will not give to a woman an abortive remedy. In purity and holiness I will guard my life and my art.
 
 I will not use the knife, not even on sufferers from stone, but will withdraw in favor of such men as are engaged in this work...."Hippocratic Oath"

 It seems kind of funny to me that a man who lived that long ago, while setting out ethical standards for doctors, included abortion, but so many people today fail to see this as ethically wrong. It seems strange to me that anyone would want to go to a doctor who would just blow off part of his creed. What other parts is he blowing off? Maybe he's a doctor who'll just forget about the part about "not prescribing deadly drugs" too, because I guess it doesn't really matter. It even states at the end: 
If I keep this oath faithfully, may I enjoy my life and practice my art, respected by all men and in all times; but if I swerve from it or violate it, may the reverse be my lot
 Why are they able to get away with this without any repercussions?

Why are they able to get away with this without any repercussions?

 
 They can take a different version of the oath, without that phrase:
 
 Click me!
 
 Keep in mind neither is legally binding.

Keep in mind neither is legally binding.

 
 That kinda wraps it up doesn't it?
Maybe not legally binding, but morally binding.
Bassman, with that remark I believe you are on what is refered to as a sticky wicket in cricketing circles :)

Maybe not legally binding, but morally binding.

 
 Read Sigma's link, and if it's not legally binding, you don't have to take it right? If you don't have to take it it's not morally binding. I don't like being binded to oaths I don't make, but I guess that's just me :)

Maybe not legally binding, but morally binding.

 
 If they feel it is morally binding (and they have to feel morally bound to be bound morally to it), they can either take the other version or, like zachvac said, not take the oath at all.
 
 

 Bassman, with that remark I believe you are on what is refered to as a sticky wicket in cricketing circles

 
 I have heard this phrase before, but my cricket jargon is not up to snuff :P What does it refer to?

I have heard this phrase before, but my cricket jargon is not up to snuff :P What does it refer to?

 
 Okay this definition is quite apt:
 
 "The term sticky wicket comes from a situation in which rain has dampened the pitch. This makes the path of the ball more unpredictable thus making the job of defending the stumps that much more difficult."
 
 Bassman is the Batsman in this analogy. Time to spin bowl him a few overs? :)
Typical of men! Trivialize a primary concern of women by injecting sports talk!

Typical of men! Trivialize a primary concern of women by injecting sports talk!

 
 Cricket isn't a sport... it's a way of life! :D

Cricket isn't a sport... it's a way of life! :D

 
 Outstanding response!

Typical of men! Trivialize a primary concern of women by injecting sports talk!

 
 Aww.... c'mom simone- it least it wasn't bowls!

Outstanding response!
Hmmm, Sigma and Occam's Razor, I see that I shall have to soundly rap you both on the knuckles with my ruler!

Hmmm, Sigma and Occam's Razor, I see that I shall have to soundly rap you both on the knuckles with my ruler!

 
 *goes and sits in the naughty-corner*

title: 4Forums.com Political Debates and Polls -  Just an Oath?
